question:
Diagrams H and I illustrate tractor-coupled implements. Use them to answer questions (a) - (c)

(a) Identify the implements illustrated by diagrams H and I.

Specimen H;                Specimen I;

           

(b) Name the parts labelled I -X.

(c) State one function of each or parts labelled I -IX.
answer:
(a) ldentification:

  • H - Disc plough.
  • I - Mouldboard plough.

(b)

  • Point of attachment to the tractor/coupling point. 
  • Beam/Frame.
  • Scrapper
  • Disc
  • Furrow wheel/reer-wheel
  • Leg/standard
  • Coulier
  • Share
  • Mouldboard
  • Standard/leg

(c) Functions of parts:

  • Provides the point of attachment to the tractor.
  • Holds the discs in position/used to increase depth of penetration.
  • Removes soil that clings to the disc during operation.
  • Makes horizontal and vertical cuts of the soil/cutting and inverting soil.
  • Provides balancing effect for the plough/ enables the plough to jump over stones or stumps.
  • Attaches the disc to the beam.
  • Makes vertical cuts/furrows.
  • Makes horizontal cuts.
  • Turns the soil over/buries weeds.

question:
(a) ldentify specimens N, O, and P.

Specimen N;          Specimen O;                       Specimen P;

                        

(b) State the relationship between specimens O and P.

(c) List five economic importance of specimen N in an aquatic ecosystem,

(d) Give three benefits of stocking both specimens O and P together in the same pond.
answer:
(a) identification of Specimens:

  • N - Water lettuce
  • O - Cat Fish,
  • P - Tilapia spp.

(b) Relationship between Catfish and Tilapia Spp: Catfish feeds on the fries/fingerlings of tilapia spp. OR Specimen O (Catfish) helps to control the population of specimen. Predator-prey relationship.

(c) Economic Importance of Specimen N in an aquatic ecosystem:

  • Hinders free movement of aquatic organisms.
  • Limits the penetration of light into ponds.
  • Hinders proper aeration.
  • Takes nutrients from the pond that could have been used by the planktons.
  • Hides fishes from being sighted by predators.
  • Some herbivorous fish feed on it. Interferes with fish harvesting.
  • Competes with fish for dissolved oxygen for root respiration.
  • Provides breeding ground for some fish species.
  • Increases cost of production of fish.
  • Makes navigation difficult.

(d) Ways of Controlling Specimen N:

  • Physical removal by hand (manual).
  • Remove it consistently/mechanically.
  • Stock an adequate number of herbivorous fishes.
  • Lime the pond properly before stocking.
